On this page

Getting Started with the GaaS Framework ‚Äã

Welcome to the Government as a Service (GaaS) framework - the complete operating model for 21st-century digital government. This guide will help you navigate the framework based on your role and goals.

Choose Your Path ‚Äã

Select your role below to get a customized learning journey:

üéØ Executive / Decision Maker

You are: Head of Government, Minister, CIO, CDO, Senior Executive

Your goal: Understand the strategic vision, build business case, secure funding

Start Here ‚Üí

üèóÔ∏è Technical Architect

You are: Solutions Architect, Enterprise Architect, Platform Engineer, CTO

Your goal: Design the technical architecture, select platforms, integrate systems

Start Here ‚Üí

‚öôÔ∏è Implementer / Project Lead

You are: Program Manager, Workstream Lead, Scrum Master, Service Manager

Your goal: Execute implementation, deliver services, manage teams

Start Here ‚Üí

üë• Citizen / Advocate

You are: Citizen, Civil Society Organization, Researcher, Journalist

Your goal: Understand digital government, advocate for better services, contribute feedback

Start Here ‚Üí

üéØ Executive / Decision Maker Path ‚Äã

Your Journey: Vision ‚Üí Strategic Case ‚Üí Investment Framework ‚Üí Governance

Step 1: Understand the Vision (15 minutes) ‚Äã

Read: The GaaS Manifesto

This 6-page vision document explains:

  • Why traditional government IT fails (70-80% failure rate)
  • The 40-40-20 PPT balance (People-Process-Technology)
  • Real-world success stories (Estonia, Singapore, UAE, Denmark)
  • The economic case: $10B+ documented savings globally

Key Takeaway: Digital government is not about buying technology - it's about building organizational capability.

Step 2: Understand the Operating Model (30 minutes) ‚Äã

Read: Framework Overview

Learn the 5-Layer Architecture + GaaS Service Value System (GSVS):

Architectural Layers:

  • Layer 0: Legal & Policy Foundation (constitutional authority)
  • Layer 1: Shared Technology Core (national platforms)
  • Layer 2: People & Process Engine (where transformation happens)
  • Layer 3: Transparent Service Portfolio (cost visibility)
  • Layer 4: Unified Citizen Experience (single front-door)

Process Engine:

  • Mandate ‚Üí Architect ‚Üí Build/Acquire ‚Üí Transition ‚Üí Deliver & Support

Key Takeaway: This is an integrated operating model, not a collection of documents.

Step 3: Build the Strategic Case (2 hours) ‚Äã

Read: Layer 3: Portfolio Management Strategic Guide

This 200+ page guide (formerly the Executive Playbook) provides:

  • Investment framework and fiscal models
  • Build vs. Buy vs. Partner decisions
  • ROI calculations and value measurement
  • Phased implementation roadmap (3-5 years)
  • Risk mitigation strategies

Key Questions Answered:

  • How much will this cost? ($50M-500M depending on country size)
  • What's the ROI? (2.5:1 to 6:1 over 5 years)
  • How long will it take? (18-36 months to operational, 5-7 years to maturity)
  • What are the risks? (Political, technical, organizational - with mitigations)

Step 4: Understand the Legal Foundation (1 hour) ‚Äã

Read: Layer 0: Legal & Policy Foundation

Explore 26+ legislative templates organized by priority:

  • Core (3 essential): Digital Identity Act, Data Protection Act, E-Government Services Act
  • Enabling (6 recommended): Cybersecurity Act, Open Data Act, Digital Signature Recognition Act
  • Operational (17 sector-specific): API Governance, Cloud-First Policy, Service Standards

Key Takeaway: You need legal authority before building platforms. Layer 0 comes first.

Step 5: See How It All Works Together (30 minutes) ‚Äã

Read: GaaS Service Value System

Understand the Service Value Chain - how policy becomes platforms, platforms enable services, and services create citizen value:

Mandate (Layer 0 Policy)
  ‚Üì
Architect (Layer 1 Blueprints + Layer 2 GSM Framework)
  ‚Üì
Build/Acquire (Layer 2 Teams + Agile Delivery)
  ‚Üì
Transition (Layer 2 ITIL Practices)
  ‚Üì
Deliver & Support (Layer 3 Portfolio + Layer 4 Experience)
  ‚Üì
Value Creation (Measured via TBM in Layer 3)
  ‚Üì
Continual Improvement (Feedback to Layer 2 Teams)

Key Takeaway: Every layer has a specific role in the value chain. All must work together.

Executive Quick Actions ‚Äã

‚úÖ Week 1: Read Manifesto, Framework Overview, and GSVS (2-3 hours total)

‚úÖ Week 2: Read Portfolio Management Strategic Guide (2-4 hours)

‚úÖ Week 3: Convene stakeholders, present vision, secure political mandate

‚úÖ Week 4: Commission skills gap analysis and fiscal feasibility study

‚úÖ Month 2-3: Draft National Digital Strategy using Layer 0 template

‚úÖ Month 4-6: Secure multi-year funding ($50M-500M), recruit Chief Digital Officer

‚úÖ Month 7-12: Establish Digital Transformation Office, begin Phase 1 implementation

üèóÔ∏è Technical Architect Path ‚Äã

Your Journey: Process Engine ‚Üí Technical Blueprints ‚Üí Integration Patterns ‚Üí Deployment

Step 1: Understand How Work Flows (30 minutes) ‚Äã

Read: GaaS Service Value System

Before diving into technical blueprints, understand the process engine that orchestrates work across layers:

  • Service Value Chain: Mandate ‚Üí Architect ‚Üí Build/Acquire ‚Üí Transition ‚Üí Deliver
  • 28 GSM Practices: How work gets coordinated (Incident, Change, Release Management)
  • Cross-Layer Dependencies: Which layer provides what capability

Key Takeaway: You're not just building technology - you're designing a system where people, processes, and technology work as one.

Step 2: Study the Shared Technology Core (2-3 hours) ‚Äã

Read: Layer 1: Shared Technology Core Overview

Understand the "Build Once, Use Everywhere" philosophy:

Core Platforms:

  • National Digital Identity (authentication & authorization)
  • API Gateway & Data Exchange (interoperability)
  • Cloud Infrastructure (compute, storage, network)
  • Analytics & AI Platform (insights & automation)
  • National Notification System (SMS, email, push)
  • Cybersecurity Operations Center (SOC)

Architecture Principles:

  • API-first design
  • Zero-trust security
  • Cloud-native (Kubernetes, serverless)
  • Open standards (OAuth 2.0, OIDC, SAML, REST/GraphQL)

Deep-Dive Blueprints:

  • Process & Service Management Architecture
  • Technology & Platform Architecture

Step 3: Understand the Operating Layer (2-3 hours) ‚Äã

Read: Layer 2: People & Process Engine Overview

This is the 40-40-20 PPT balance in action:

People Dimension (40%):

  • GaaS Workforce Blueprint - 200-500+ digital roles
  • Digital Talent Strategy - Recruit and retain

Process Dimension (40%):

  • 10 Process Playbooks covering:
    • Strategy & Design: Digital Identity, Co-Design, Service Portfolio
    • Build & Deploy: API Gateway, Agile Delivery
    • Secure & Govern: Zero Trust, Cybersecurity, Data Governance
    • Operate & Improve: GSM Implementation, Change Management

Technology Dimension (20%):

  • Enablers from Layer 1 platforms

Key Takeaway: Your architecture must support people and processes, not just run software.

Step 4: Explore Implementation Playbooks (3-4 hours) ‚Äã

Browse: Layer 2 Process Playbooks

Each playbook provides 18-30 month implementation roadmaps:

Technical Playbooks:

  • Process: Digital Identity - NIST 800-63, eIDAS compliance
  • Process: API Gateway - Kong, Apigee, AWS API Gateway patterns
  • Process: Zero Trust Migration - NIST 800-207 implementation

Operational Playbooks:

  • Process: GSM Implementation - ITIL v4 for government
  • Process: Service Portfolio & Cost Management - TBM framework

Key Takeaway: These aren't theoretical guides - they're battle-tested playbooks from Estonia, Singapore, UAE.

Step 5: Study Integration Patterns (1 hour) ‚Äã

Read: Layer overview "Integration with Other Layers" sections:

  • Layer 1 Integration
  • Layer 2 Integration
  • Layer 3 Integration

Key Integration Points:

  • Layer 0 provides legal authority for data sharing ‚Üí Layer 1 implements technical controls
  • Layer 1 provides APIs ‚Üí Layer 2 teams consume and operate them
  • Layer 2 produces services ‚Üí Layer 3 manages their portfolio and costs
  • Layer 3 exposes services ‚Üí Layer 4 presents unified citizen experience

Architect Quick Actions ‚Äã

‚úÖ Week 1: Read GSVS + Layer 1 Overview + Layer 2 Overview (4-6 hours)

‚úÖ Week 2: Deep-dive into technical blueprints (Volumes 2 & 3) (8-12 hours)

‚úÖ Week 3: Review relevant process playbooks for your workstreams (6-10 hours)

‚úÖ Week 4: Draft high-level architecture diagrams using GaaS patterns

‚úÖ Month 2: Design API contracts and integration patterns

‚úÖ Month 3: Select technology stack (cloud provider, identity platform, API gateway)

‚úÖ Month 4-6: Build proof-of-concept for core Layer 1 platforms

‚öôÔ∏è Implementer / Project Lead Path ‚Äã

Your Journey: Process Playbooks ‚Üí Policy Templates ‚Üí Platform Guides ‚Üí Execution

Step 1: Start with Process Playbooks (3-5 hours) ‚Äã

Browse: Layer 2 Process Playbooks

Pick the playbooks most relevant to your workstream:

If you're implementing Identity:

  • Process: Digital Identity - 18-month roadmap

If you're building API Platform:

  • Process: API Gateway - Deployment guide

If you're leading Change Management:

  • Process: Change Management & Training - Adoption strategies

If you're establishing Service Management:

  • Process: GSM Implementation - ITIL for government

Each playbook provides:

  • Step-by-step implementation phases
  • Resource requirements (people, budget, tools)
  • Success criteria and KPIs
  • Risk mitigation strategies
  • Real-world case studies

Step 2: Get the Policy Templates (1-2 hours) ‚Äã

Browse: Layer 0: Legal & Policy Foundation

Download templates you need:

For Technical Workstreams:

  • API Governance Policy
  • Cloud First Policy
  • Technology Selection Framework

For Operational Workstreams:

  • Incident Management Policy
  • Change Management Policy
  • Service Level Management Policy

For Governance:

  • Digital Transformation Office Charter
  • PPT Balance Policy

Key Takeaway: Adapt these templates to your jurisdiction - don't copy-paste.

Step 3: Understand the Platform Context (1 hour) ‚Äã

Read: Layer 1: Shared Technology Core Overview

Even if you're not building Layer 1 platforms yourself, you need to understand:

  • What platforms will exist (Identity, API Gateway, Cloud, Analytics)
  • When they'll be available (phased rollout)
  • How to consume them (API documentation, SDKs)
  • Who to contact for support (platform team SLAs)

Key Takeaway: You'll consume Layer 1 capabilities to build Layer 3 services.

Step 4: Learn Service Management Practices (2-3 hours) ‚Äã

Read: Process: GSM Implementation

Even if this isn't your primary workstream, you need to understand:

  • Incident Management: How to respond when services fail
  • Change Management: How to coordinate releases and deployments
  • Service Catalog: How to register your services
  • SLA Framework: What uptime and performance targets you must meet

Key Takeaway: All workstreams operate within the GSM framework.

Step 5: Join the Community (30 minutes) ‚Äã

Read: Layer 4: Community Platform

Connect with global practitioners:

  • Join discussion forums
  • Attend regional workshops
  • Share your implementation experiences
  • Get help from peers who've faced similar challenges

Implementer Quick Actions ‚Äã

‚úÖ Week 1: Read relevant process playbook for your workstream (3-5 hours)

‚úÖ Week 2: Download and adapt policy templates (2-3 hours)

‚úÖ Week 3: Build project plan using playbook phases as milestones

‚úÖ Week 4: Identify skill gaps and resource requirements

‚úÖ Month 2: Begin Phase 1 implementation (foundation building)

‚úÖ Month 3-6: Execute Phase 1, track KPIs, adjust plan based on learnings

‚úÖ Month 7-18: Execute Phase 2 (capability building and scaling)

üë• Citizen / Advocate Path ‚Äã

Your Journey: Vision ‚Üí Citizen Experience ‚Üí Co-Design ‚Üí Community

Step 1: Understand the Vision (15 minutes) ‚Äã

Read: The GaaS Manifesto

Learn what digital government means for you:

  • Contactless: Government services available 24/7 on your phone
  • Intelligent: AI-powered services that anticipate your needs
  • Automated: Instant responses, no waiting in queues
  • Persistent: Government remembers you (securely)
  • Secure: Your privacy and data protected

Real-World Examples:

  • Estonia: 99% of services online, 15 minutes average interaction time per year
  • Singapore: 97% adoption, 4M+ users, 95% satisfaction
  • Denmark: 90% digital adoption, mandatory digital post system

Step 2: Explore the Citizen Experience (30 minutes) ‚Äã

Read: Layer 4: Unified Citizen Experience

Discover what a digital government looks like:

Unified Portal:

  • Single login for all government services (digital identity)
  • Personalized dashboard showing your services, benefits, obligations
  • Proactive notifications (e.g., "Your passport expires in 60 days")

Once-Only Principle:

  • Never re-enter data government already has
  • Pre-filled forms with your information
  • Seamless data sharing (with your consent)

Omnichannel Access:

  • Web portal, mobile app, voice assistant, in-person kiosks
  • Same experience across all channels
  • Assisted digital support for those who need help

Step 3: Understand Your Rights and Protections (30 minutes) ‚Äã

Browse: Layer 0: Legal & Policy Foundation

Learn about the laws that protect you:

Data Protection:

  • Data Protection & Privacy Act - Your data rights
  • Data Sharing Framework - How government shares data (with consent)

Transparency:

  • Open Data & Transparency Act - Access to government data
  • Algorithmic Accountability Policy - AI transparency

Digital Rights:

  • Digital Identity Act - Your digital identity rights
  • E-Government Services Act - Right to digital services

Step 4: Participate in Co-Design (1 hour) ‚Äã

Read: Community Platform Overview

Your voice matters in shaping digital government:

Ways to Participate:

  • User Testing: Test new services before public launch
  • Feedback Forums: Share your experience with existing services
  • Co-Design Workshops: Help design services that meet your needs
  • Citizen Advisory Councils: Represent citizen perspective in governance

Real-World Example: Singapore's LifeSG app was co-designed with 5,000+ citizens through workshops, surveys, and usability testing over 18 months.

Step 5: Advocate for Better Services (30 minutes) ‚Äã

Use the Framework to Advocate:

When lobbying for better digital government, cite specific GaaS principles:

  • "Our country should adopt the 40-40-20 PPT balance - we're spending 80% on technology and 10% on people/process"
  • "We need a National Digital Identity like Estonia's e-ID or Singapore's SingPass"
  • "Government should implement the Once-Only Principle so I don't re-enter data"
  • "We need TBM cost transparency - show me how my taxes are spent on digital services"

Share Success Stories:

  • Estonia saves ‚Ç¨100M/year through digital government
  • Singapore's Singpass generates $385M annual value
  • UAE achieved 95%+ citizen satisfaction

Citizen Quick Actions ‚Äã

‚úÖ Today: Read the Manifesto (15 minutes)

‚úÖ This Week: Explore Layer 4 Citizen Experience (30 minutes)

‚úÖ This Month: Join community forums and share your service experiences

‚úÖ Ongoing: Advocate for digital government in your community

What If I Don't Fit These Roles? ‚Äã

Researcher / Academic:

  • Start with Framework Overview to understand the complete model
  • Explore GSVS for theoretical foundation
  • Use Layer 0 as policy research
  • Access Implementation Registry for case studies

Developer / Engineer:

  • Start with Layer 1: Technology Architecture
  • Review Technical Blueprints
  • Explore Process: API Gateway
  • (Future) Reference implementations coming soon

Vendor / Technology Partner:

  • Start with Framework Overview to understand GaaS architecture
  • Review Layer 1 for platform specifications
  • Study Layer 2 Playbooks for implementation patterns
  • Ensure your solutions align with GaaS principles (open standards, API-first, zero-trust)

Procurement Specialist:

  • Start with Layer 3: Portfolio Management
  • Review Fiscal Architecture for funding models
  • Study Greenfield Implementation Guide
  • Download Technology Selection Framework

Need Help? ‚Äã

Stuck? Not sure where to start?

  1. Read the Framework Overview - 10 pages that explain everything
  2. Join Community Discussions
  3. Contact us: info@gaas.global

Want updates?

  • Star us on GitHub
  • Follow the Implementation Registry for real-world adoptions

What's Next? ‚Äã

Once you've completed your learning path above, consider:

For Executives:

  • Draft your National Digital Strategy
  • Secure political mandate and funding
  • Recruit your Chief Digital Officer
  • Establish Digital Transformation Office

For Architects:

  • Design high-level architecture using GaaS patterns
  • Select technology stack (cloud, identity, API gateway)
  • Build proof-of-concept integrations
  • Document platform standards

For Implementers:

  • Build detailed project plans from process playbooks
  • Secure resources (people, budget, tools)
  • Begin Phase 1 implementation
  • Establish feedback loops and KPI tracking

For Citizens:

  • Participate in co-design workshops
  • Provide feedback on existing services
  • Advocate for digital government in your community
  • Hold government accountable to GaaS principles

Ready? Choose your path above and start your journey! üöÄ
